phrasebook.title: Star in a Box
stages: Deeply or fully convective low mass MS star

about.title: About
about.content:
Star in a Box allows you to explore one of the most enigmatic tools in astronomy - the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram.

When you first open the box you start with a star with the same mass as the Sun but you can change this to a different mass at any time. The tracks that you see on the graph (on the left) map the lifecycle of the star. You can play the animation of the star moving around the diagram, and see how its luminosity, size, surface temperature, and mass change in the panels on the right.

Stars can take billions of years to go through their lives with the dramatic events taking place in relatively short periods of time. In the animation we speed up time when the star is not really changing much and slow things down for the dramatic phases of the star's life.

Keyboard controls:

%CONTROLLIST%

Acknowledgments

Design & Development: Jon Yardley, Stuart Lowe, Edward Gomez, Haley Gomez & Chris North

Supported by LCOGT & Cardiff University

Based on the stellar evolution research of Jarrod Hurley, Onno Pols, and Christopher Tout

intro.title: Welcome!
intro.content:
You are now the proud owner of Star In A Box.

Inside this box you can animate the different stages in a star's life and see how its luminosity, size, and mass change with time.

Once you've opened the box just click the play button to start animating.

phrasebook.preparing:
Your star is being prepared.

Please wait...

content.m0_2:
0.2 Solar Masses

Deep or Fully Convective Low Mass MS star

The star is in a very stable state, fusing (or burning) hydrogen atoms in the core. The star is convective throughout, rather than just having convective zones, as is found in more massive stars of around a solar mass or more.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes color to give a more red appearance.

Helium White Dwarf

Main-sequence stars of around half a solar mass or less do not become hot enough to burn helium in their cores. The star burns out all of its hydrogen and ends its evolution as a helium white dwarf, composed mainly of helium-4 nuclei.
content.m0_65:
0.65 Solar Masses

Deep or Fully Convective Low Mass MS star

The star is in a very stable state, fusing (or burning) hydrogen atoms in the core. The star is convective throughout, rather than just having convective zones, as is found in more massive stars of around a solar mass or more.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes color to give a more red appearance.

Helium White Dwarf

Main-sequence stars of around half a solar mass or less do not become hot enough to burn helium in their cores. The star burns out all of its hydrogen and ends its evolution as a helium white dwarf, composed mainly of helium-4 nuclei.
content.m1:
1 Solar Mass

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for billions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes color to give a more red appearance.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Asymptotic Giant Branch

After a star has consumed the helium in its core, fusion then continues in a shell around a hot core of carbon and oxygen, but below the hydrogen burning shell, we can revisit our onion analogy adding an outer hydrogen layer, an inner carbon/oxygen core, and a helium layer between. The outer layers of the star swell, cool and change color again as it did in the Red Giant Branch phase.

Thermally-Pulsing Asymptotic Giant Branch

The helium burning shell produces a hundred to a million times as much energy produced by the hydrogen burning shell over a short time period. This causes energy bursts, in the form of thermal pulses between these layers.

Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf

If the star is massive enough, as in this case, it will be able to fuse helium into carbon and oxygen via the triple-alpha process, but will not be hot enough to fuse carbon-oxygen core into heavier elements. The hydrogen and helium layers will be cast out into a planetary nebula, leaving the carbon-oxygen core.
content.m2:
2 Solar Mass

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for billions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes color to give a more red appearance.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Asymptotic Giant Branch

After a star has consumed the helium in its core, fusion then continues in a shell around a hot core of carbon and oxygen, but below the hydrogen burning shell, we can revisit our onion analogy adding an outer hydrogen layer, an inner carbon/oxygen core, and a helium layer between. The outer layers of the star swell, cool and change color again as it did in the Red Giant Branch phase.

Thermally-Pulsing Asymptotic Giant Branch

The helium burning shell produces a hundred to a million times as much energy produced by the hydrogen burning shell over a short time period. This causes energy bursts, in the form of thermal pulses between these layers.

Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf

If the star is massive enough, as in this case, it will be able to fuse helium into carbon and oxygen via the triple-alpha process, but will not be hot enough to fuse carbon-oxygen core into heavier elements. The hydrogen and helium layers will be cast out into a planetary nebula, leaving the carbon-oxygen core.

4 Solar Mass

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for millions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes color to give a more red appearance.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Asymptotic Giant Branch

After a star has consumed the helium in its core, fusion then continues in a shell around a hot core of carbon and oxygen, but below the hydrogen burning shell, we can revisit our onion analogy adding an outer hydrogen layer, an inner carbon/oxygen core, and a helium layer between. The outer layers of the star swell, cool and change color again as it did in the Red Giant Branch phase.

Thermally-Pulsing Asymptotic Giant Branch

The helium burning shell produces a hundred to a million times as much energy produced by the hydrogen burning shell over a short time period. This causes energy bursts, in the form of thermal pulses between these layers.

Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf

If the star is massive enough, as in this case, it will be able to fuse helium into carbon and oxygen via the triple-alpha process, but will not be hot enough to fuse carbon-oxygen core into heavier elements. The hydrogen and helium layers will be cast out into a planetary nebula, leaving the carbon-oxygen core.
content.m6:
6 Solar Mass

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for millions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes color to give a more red appearance.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Asymptotic Giant Branch

After a star has consumed the helium in its core, fusion then continues in a shell around a hot core of carbon and oxygen, but below the hydrogen burning shell, we can revisit our onion analogy adding an outer hydrogen layer, an inner carbon/oxygen core, and a helium layer between. The outer layers of the star swell, cool and change color again as it did in the Red Giant Branch phase.

Thermally-Pulsing Asymptotic Giant Branch

The helium burning shell produces a hundred to a million times as much energy produced by the hydrogen burning shell over a short time period. This causes energy bursts, in the form of thermal pulses between these layers.

Carbon/Oxygen White Dwarf

If the star is massive enough, as in this case, it will be able to fuse helium into carbon and oxygen via the triple-alpha process, but will not be hot enough to fuse carbon-oxygen core into heavier elements. The hydrogen and helium layers will be cast out into a planetary nebula, leaving the carbon-oxygen core.
content.m10:
10 Solar Mass

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for millions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes color to give a more red appearance.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Asymptotic Giant Branch

After a star has consumed the helium in its core, fusion then continues in a shell around a hot core of carbon and oxygen, but below the hydrogen burning shell, we can revisit our onion analogy adding an outer hydrogen layer, an inner carbon/oxygen core, and a helium layer between. The outer layers of the star swell, cool and change color again as it did in the Red Giant Branch phase.

Neutron Star

A star of more than 8 times the mass of the Sun will be able to reach a temperature in the core that makes it suitable to fuse carbon and oxygen atoms to make heavier elements. The elements carry on fusing, adding more and more layers like in the onion analogy. However, the fusion stops with iron, and since energy is no longer being released from nuclear reactions, gravity causes the core to collapse, and the outer layers of the star explodes in a supernova, a very bright event lasting months, leaving a Neutron Star behind, a star with a mass greater than the Sun, but around the size of Brooklyn. Neutron stars spin very rapidly given by their high mass and low radius. Since most of the stars radiation is spent during the Supernova, the Neutron Star is very dim, giving out radio waves like beacons from the top and bottom of the magnetic fields. Coupled with the spin, these beacons act like a distant radio-lighthouse in space.
content.m20:
20 Solar Mass

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for millions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Red Giant Branch

A very rapid phase takes place where the stellar core is depleted of hydrogen leaving a helium core that contracts rapidly and heats up. While there is very little hydrogen in the core, a shell surrounding the core continues to burn; we can think of an onion analogy where the star has layers, and in this case there is an outer hydrogen layer, and an inner helium layer. As the core contracts the outer layers expand and cool and the star begins to inflate and changes color to give a more red appearance.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Asymptotic Giant Branch

After a star has consumed the helium in its core, fusion then continues in a shell around a hot core of carbon and oxygen, but below the hydrogen burning shell, we can revisit our onion analogy adding an outer hydrogen layer, an inner carbon/oxygen core, and a helium layer between. The outer layers of the star swell, cool and change color again as it did in the Red Giant Branch phase.

Neutron Star

A star of more than 8 times the mass of the Sun will be able to reach a temperature in the core that makes it suitable to fuse carbon and oxygen atoms to make heavier elements. The elements carry on fusing, adding more and more layers like in the onion analogy. However, the fusion stops with iron, and since energy is no longer being released from nuclear reactions, gravity causes the core to collapse, and the outer layers of the star explodes in a supernova, a very bright event lasting months, leaving a Neutron Star behind, a star with a mass greater than the Sun, but around the size of Brooklyn. Neutron stars spin very rapidly given by their high mass and low radius. Since most of the stars radiation is spent during the Supernova, the Neutron Star is very dim, giving out radio waves like beacons from the top and bottom of the magnetic fields. Coupled with the spin, these beacons act like a distant radio-lighthouse in space.
content.m30:
30 Solar Masses

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for millions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Main Sequence Naked Helium Star

During this stage, the star is giving off rapid stellar winds, these winds strip the star of its hydrogen envelope, leaving the helium core behind. At this stage the star appears blue, and has a very, very hot surface temperature.

Wolf-Rayet Star

By now, the star is no longer fusing elements in its core, and its outer layers are fading away due to the rapid stellar winds of up to 2000km per second, which is significantly shortening its lifetime, as a supernova looms.

Black Hole

Due to the lack of activity in the core, there is no pressure to stop gravity from causing the core to collapse. A supernova occurs, and the core collapses. Left over is a Black hole, an object with such a strong gravitational field, that anything that falls on it can’t escape, not even light (hence the name 'Black').
content.m40:
40 Solar Masses

Main Sequence

The stage longest inhabited by a star. The star remains stable for millions of years burning (or fusing) hydrogen at its core.

Hertzsprung Gap

The phase of evolution when a star has finished fusing hydrogen atoms in the core, but has not yet started burning helium.

Core Helium Burning

At this stage, for stars around a solar mass to 8 solar masses, the core now filled with helium, heats up until it is hot enough to burn helium. Eventually the core reaches a temperature so high the density of matter is high enough that gravity is counteracted, and the star to expands and subsequently cools.

Main Sequence Naked Helium Star

During this stage, the star is giving off rapid stellar winds, these winds strip the star of its hydrogen envelope, leaving the helium core behind. At this stage the star appears blue, and has a very, very hot surface temperature.

Wolf-Rayet Star

By now, the star is no longer fusing elements in its core, and its outer layers are fading away due to the rapid stellar winds of up to 2000km per second, which is significantly shortening its lifetime, as a supernova looms.

Black Hole

Due to the lack of activity in the core, there is no pressure to stop gravity from causing the core to collapse. A supernova occurs, and the core collapses. Left over is a Black hole, an object with such a strong gravitational field, that anything that falls on it can’t escape, not even light (hence the name 'Black').

tutorial: Welcome! At the moment you have a 1 solar mass star but you can change that here if you want to.
This is your star at the start of its life. The dashed line shows how the star's luminosity and temperature will change over its life.
Click the play button when you're ready to start animating your star.

captions.rScales:
Mass

This shows how the mass of your star varies over its life. Stars lose mass gradually by converting hydrogen into helium and heavier elements. They can also lose mass through winds blowing off their surface and at dramatic moments in their lives.

Stars are massive so, rather than measure this in kilograms, we measure this in comparison to our Sun which has 1 Solar Mass - which is about 2 million million million million million kg!
captions.rStopwatch:
Stages in your star's life

This stopwatch shows the relative time the star spends in each stage of its life. In the animation we speed up time when the star is not really changing much and slow things down for the dramatic phases of the star's life.
captions.rlum:
Luminosity

How the luminosity of your star changes compared to the current luminosity of our Sun (which has a value of 1 in this light meter).

This light meter also changes color to match your star.
captions.thermometer:
Surface Temperature

How the surface temperature of your star changes with time. The temperatures are given in Kelvin which is usually abbreviated to K. Remember that:

0°C = 273 K
captions.rCanvas:
Size

How your star changes in size and color, compared to the current conditions of the Sun.

error.starload: The star failed to form. Please try again later.
